items.title: I'm Boris and I created Claude Code. Lots of people have asked how I use Claude Code, so I wanted to...
items.content:
I'm Boris and I created Claude Code. Lots of people have asked how I use Claude Code, so I wanted to show off my setup a bit.

My setup might be surprisingly vanilla! Claude Code works great out of the box, so I personally don't customize it much. There is no one correct way to use Claude Code: we intentionally build it in a way that you can use it, customize it, and hack it however you like. Each person on the Claude Code team uses it very differently.

So, here goes.
items.author: @bcherny
items.summary: Boris Cherny, creator of Claude Code, introduces a comprehensive thread sharing his personal setup and workflow for using Claude Code. Notes that his setup is 'surprisingly vanilla' and emphasizes the tool works great out of the box with customization being optional.
items.reasoning: Creator of Claude Code sharing authoritative insider knowledge with massive engagement (7.2M views, 50K likes). Primary source for best practices and intended usage patterns.

items.title:
RLHF Book status update: lot's of great changes.

Over the past month I've been doing a top to botto...
items.content:
RLHF Book status update: lot's of great changes.

Over the past month I've been doing a top to bottom update to the RLHF book. All of these changes are reflected on the website rlhfbook dot com, and will soon be translated to the Manning early access version (MEAP), and then more improvements for the physical copy.

Overall, this took the PDF from ~150 to ~200 pages, the book is much more well rounded now.

Some of the larger changes:

- Updates to the RL chapter to add more algorithms like GSPO, CISPO, etc. 
- Updated the big table of reasoning model tech reports (full list below). Added a section on Rubrics for RLVR. 
- Updated the text in many chapters to better reflect best practices of today.
- Many clarity fixes throughout, adding better transitions, introductions, etc.
- More consistent notation throughout the book.

I strongly recommend taking a look again if you only looked in the first half of 2025. There are also many surprising details, such as fixing this attached RLHF system diagram you may recognize from my first HuggingFace RLHF blog post in December of 2022, it had a bunch of minor errors.

Next step I'm going to be focusing on making the physical Manning book great. The content will flow more smoothly than the web version (i'm trying to not change the links), such as linking the constitutional AI and synthetic data chapters. Overall this should make it read better from front to back. Also, all the diagrams and content will be designed to have a much more elegant presentation. 

Thanks for reading and feedback!

items.reasoning: Highest importance - Nathan Lambert's comprehensive RLHF book update with substantial new content on modern RL algorithms and reasoning. 784 likes, 46K views. Foundational educational resource for the field

items.title: 13/ A final tip: probably the most important thing to get great results out of Claude Code -- give C...
items.content:
13/ A final tip: probably the most important thing to get great results out of Claude Code -- give Claude a way to verify its work. If Claude has that feedback loop, it will 2-3x the quality of the final result.

Claude tests every single change I land to https://t.co/pEWPQoSq5t using the Claude Chrome extension. It opens a browser, tests the UI, and iterates until the code works and the UX feels good.

Verification looks different for each domain. It might be as simple as running a bash command, or running a test suite, or testing the app in a browser or phone simulator. Make sure to invest in making this rock-solid.

https://t.co/m7wwQUmp1C
items.author: @bcherny
items.summary: Key tip: Give Claude a way to verify its work for 2-3x quality improvement. Claude tests every change to claude.ai using Chrome extension - opens browser, tests UI, iterates until code works and UX is good.
items.reasoning: Core insight on AI agent effectiveness through feedback loops. 384K views. Describes verification as 'most important thing' for quality results.

Other teams maintain their own https://t.co/pp5TJkWmFE's. It is each team's job to keep theirs up to date.

items.title: The only AI company that has any significant know-how today is Anthropic. No one is even close to wh...
items.content:
The only AI company that has any significant know-how today is Anthropic. No one is even close to what Claude Code can do with code.

This is the only use case that has a measurable impact on society: The concept of a junior or mid-level developer is gone, and the projects that these two categories of developers were capable of building in months are now built in hours or, in some cases, days.

All other AI use cases are either fun but useless, or not ready for prime time, or niche, or it's impossible to compare whose tech is better: they all look the same to the user.

items.title: 6/ Most sessions start in Plan mode (shift+tab twice). If my goal is to write a Pull Request, I will...
items.content: 6/ Most sessions start in Plan mode (shift+tab twice). If my goal is to write a Pull Request, I will use Plan mode, and go back and forth with Claude until I like its plan. From there, I switch into auto-accept edits mode and Claude can usually 1-shot it. A good plan is really important!

items.title: Honorable Mention at ICLR 2025, this paper solves a real problem that matters if you care about unde...
items.content:
Honorable Mention at ICLR 2025, this paper solves a real problem that matters if you care about understanding what training data actually does to neural networks. For years, Data Shapley has been the theoretically sound way to attribute value to training data, but nobody could use it on anything larger than toy models because it required retraining on exponentially many data subsets.

This work shows you can get Shapley values during a single training run by decomposing the attribution problem into per-iteration contributions and computing them efficiently through clever manipulation of gradients during backpropagation.

Beyond the technical contribution, the empirical findings show that around 16% of the already-curated Pile dataset has negative contribution; removing it speeds up training by 25%.

Read online and ask questions when blocked: https://t.co/2an5LXCeyI

Download a PDF: https://t.co/5yDEM94Isq
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov highlights ICLR 2025 Honorable Mention paper on efficient Data Shapley computation during single training run, finding 16% of Pile dataset has negative contribution
items.reasoning: Technical breakthrough enabling practical data attribution; 25% training speedup finding; high engagement; important for data curation

items.title: 7/ I use slash commands for every "inner loop" workflow that I end up doing many times a day. This s...
items.content:
7/ I use slash commands for every "inner loop" workflow that I end up doing many times a day. This saves me from repeated prompting, and makes it so Claude can use these workflows, too. Commands are checked into git and live in .claude/commands/.

For example, Claude and I use a /commit-push-pr slash command dozens of times every day. The command uses inline bash to pre-compute git status and a few other pieces of info to make the command run quickly and avoid back-and-forth with the model (https://t.co/4jZ7RK0suT)
items.author: @bcherny
items.summary: Boris uses slash commands for repetitive 'inner loop' workflows done many times daily. Commands are checked into git in .claude/commands/. Example: /commit-push-pr uses inline bash to pre-compute git status for speed.
items.reasoning: Detailed technical guidance on automating frequent developer workflows. 401K views. Actionable patterns for Claude Code customization.

items.title: Thanks to AI, the job of more and more people will be to manage a fleet of AI agents by posing the r...
items.content:
Thanks to AI, the job of more and more people will be to manage a fleet of AI agents by posing the right questions to them and evaluating their performance.

Call it the rise of the CQO, the "Chief Question Officer".
items.author: @erikbryn
items.summary: Erik Brynjolfsson predicts that AI will create a new role: the 'Chief Question Officer' (CQO) - people who manage fleets of AI agents by posing questions and evaluating their performance
items.reasoning: Original insight from recognized MIT economist and AI researcher. High engagement (115 likes, 21K views). Introduces novel framing for AI workforce evolution

items.title: 12/ For very long-running tasks, I will either (a) prompt Claude to verify its work with a backgroun...
items.content:
12/ For very long-running tasks, I will either (a) prompt Claude to verify its work with a background agent when it's done, (b) use an agent Stop hook to do that more deterministically, or (c) use the ralph-wiggum plugin (originally dreamt up by @GeoffreyHuntley). I will also use either --permission-mode=dontAsk or --dangerously-skip-permissions in a sandbox to avoid permission prompts for the session, so Claude can cook without being blocked on me.

https://t.co/floA4sI7FR

https://t.co/klOPZPPgIU

items.summary: For long-running tasks: use background agent verification, agent Stop hooks, or ralph-wiggum plugin. Uses --permission-mode=dontAsk or --dangerously-skip-permissions in sandbox for unblocked operation.
items.reasoning: Advanced patterns for autonomous long-running AI tasks. 336K views. Addresses practical challenges of extended AI sessions.

items.title: One of the fundamental papers that advanced our understanding of deep neural networks and led to the...
items.content:
One of the fundamental papers that advanced our understanding of deep neural networks and led to the AI that we have today.

At the time, researchers struggled with training neural networks with even two hidden layers (the weights between the input and the output of the neural networks). The problem was that the gradient signal didn't reach the weights closer to the input, which prevented the neural network from learning how to encode the inputs into something meaningful.

Among the most important discoveries that allowed training deep networks was Xavier initialization (named after the paper's first author, Xavier Glorot).

The key insight: if weights are initialized with the wrong variance, signals either explode or vanish as they pass through layers—in both directions (forward activations and backward gradients).

Their solution was elegantly simple: initialize weights from a uniform distribution scaled by both the input and output layer sizes.

This keeps the variance of activations and gradients roughly constant across layers, allowing learning signals to flow through the entire network.

The paper also showed why sigmoid activations were problematic (their non-zero mean pushes outputs toward saturation), paving the way for tanh and later ReLU dominance.

Published in 2010, this work—alongside He initialization (2015) for ReLU networks—became foundational to training the deep networks that power modern AI.

Read by asking clarifying questions: https://t.co/IakAN1rZJu

Download PDF: https://t.co/60R0Bl2Ce0
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov explains Xavier initialization paper significance - solved gradient vanishing/exploding in deep networks through proper weight initialization scaling
items.reasoning: Educational content on foundational ML technique; high engagement (316 likes); good technical depth

I thought that the issue was in my implementation of the architecture, but I just used the default PyTorch initialization. When I replaced it with Xavier, it started to work.

Maybe the transformer was invented many times earlier, but when scientists tried it, the outcome wasn't good because they didn't initialize it properly?

items.title:
Gemini:
The single best investment is an official 1297 exemplification (copy) of the Magna Carta.
1....
items.content:
Gemini:
The single best investment is an official 1297 exemplification (copy) of the Magna Carta.
1. The Investment: 1297 Magna Carta Exemplification
In 1300, the Magna Carta was not an ancient relic but an active legal statute. King Edward I had issued a confirmation (inspeximus) of the Charter in 1297. You could acquire an official copy from the Royal Chancery or a highly skilled scrivener.
 * The Asset: A single parchment sheet inscribed with the Magna Carta, bearing the royal seal (or the seal of the Chancery).
 * The Value Today: In 2007, a 1297 Magna Carta (the "Brudenell" copy) sold at Sotheby's for $21.3 million.
 * The Return on Investment: Approximately 2,000,000% (adjusted for inflation and purchasing power).
2. Can You Afford It? ($1,000 Budget Analysis)
Yes, but barely. We must convert your $1,000 (2026 USD) into 1300 purchasing power:
 * Gold Standard: $1,000 USD (2026) is roughly equivalent to 0.3–0.4 oz of gold.
 * 1300 Currency: This equals approximately 3 to 3.5 Florentine Gold Florins.
 * Exchange Rate: In 1300, 1 Gold Florin was worth roughly 6 shillings (s).
 * Total Budget: You have roughly 18 to 21 shillings (~£1).
 * Cost of the Item: Administrative fees for royal writs and charters typically ranged from a "mark" (13s 4d) to £1, depending on the complexity. Since you are requesting a copy of an existing statute, the cost would be primarily the scribe's labor and the sealing fee. With ~20 shillings, you have just enough to pay the Chancery fees for one high-quality, official document.
3. The Strategy: "The Institutional Trust"
You cannot bury this (it will rot) or hide it (it will be lost). You must use the only entities that have survived 700 years of war: The Church or The University.
 * Action: Take your fresh Magna Carta to Durham Cathedral (founded 1093) or Westminster Abbey.
 * The Deal: Deposit the document in the Cathedral Priory's archives under a "Deed of Deposit" (not a gift). Frame it as a holy relic of the law, entrusted to the church for safekeeping for your "descendants."
 * Why It Survives:
   * Durham Cathedral has never been sacked or burned down since 1300. Its library has maintained continuous records for nearly a millennium.
   * Even during the Dissolution of the Monasteries (1539), Durham's priory was simply converted into a secular chapter; the books and charters remained on the shelves.
   * During the English Civil War and WWII, these archives were protected as national heritage.
4. Why This Beats Other Investments
| Investment | 1300 Cost | 2026 Status | Why it Fails/Loses |
|---|---|---|---|
| London Real Estate | ~£2 - £50 | Billions | Failed: You cannot afford the freehold (£2+) with your £1 budget. Even if you bought a lease, maintaining legal title through the Black Death (1348) and Great Fire (1666) without being present is legally impossible. |
| Stora Enso Shares | >£10 | Stock | Failed: While the company (copper mine) existed in 1288, a share (1/8th of the mine) cost far more than 3 Florins. Furthermore, share dilution and mergers over 700 years would likely wipe out your equity. |
| Giotto Painting | ~5-10 Florins | $50M+ | Risky: A panel by Giotto (active 1300) is a great candidate, but slightly out of your budget. Art is also easier to loot, burn, or re-attribute than a stamped royal charter. |
| Magna Carta | ~1 Mark (13s 4d) | $21.3M | Winner: Verified market value, durable material (parchment), protected by lawyers and clerics, distinct "brand" recognition. |
5. Summary
By spending your 18 shillings (approx. $1000 2026 USD) on an official Chancery copy of the Magna Carta and depositing it in the archives of Durham Cathedral, you utilize the stability of English ecclesiastical record-keeping to bypass wars and revolutions. You are creating a verifiable chain of custody that turns a modest administrative fee into a $21.3 million asset.

items.title:
ChatGPT: 

Buy a documented ownership share in the Great Copper Mountain at Falun (Stora Kopparberg)...
items.content:
ChatGPT: 

Buy a documented ownership share in the Great Copper Mountain at Falun (Stora Kopparberg), Sweden

Why this is the best candidate that actually clears your survivability rule

This isn’t just “buy land and hope.” Falun is one of the rare cases where we have (a) medieval-era documentary evidence, (b) an early share-like ownership structure, and (c) continuity into a modern successor company.

Key points, with sources:
•The Great Copper Mountain (Falun) has surviving documentation from 1288 and a major charter dated 1347.  
•That charter-era operation is described by ICOMOS (UNESCO’s advisory body) as being organized “as a corporate operation” where free miners (bergsmän) owned shares (“fjärdeparter”) proportional to their interests—explicitly calling it a precursor to later joint-stock companies and noting it’s often referred to as “the oldest company in the world.”  
•The Swedish History Museum describes the medieval bergslag business organizations (from the 13th century onward) where members owned shares of a mine or smelting furnace—i.e., a real, historically grounded “equity-like” structure you can buy into around 1300.  
•There is a well-known 1288 share document associated with the mine (a share entitling the holder to 1/8 of the Great Copper Mine), and the Wikimedia description notes the original is in Sweden’s National Archives (Riksarkivet) with a copy in the Stora Enso archive in Falun.  
•ICOMOS describes the enterprise’s later evolution: it notes the “old company” was reconstituted as a modern limited company in 1888 (Stora Kopparbergs Bergslags AB).  
•Stora Enso itself (the modern, publicly traded successor through corporate evolution/merger) explicitly dates its first recorded documentation to 1288 copper mining near Falun, notes progression to Stora Kopparbergs Bergslag, and states Stora Enso was formed in 1998 via merger.  
•A mainstream historical write-up (LA Times) also recounts the famous 1288 transaction (a bishop trading property for a one‑eighth interest), framing it as a basis for the “oldest continuously operating company” claim.  

Why this is unusually robust against “regime change risk”

To meet your “90% chance” requirement, you want something that is not dependent on a single dynasty, a single city-state’s solvency, or an easily confiscated stash of precious metal.

Falun/Stora Kopparberg has a few structural advantages versus the usual time-travel answers:
1.The underlying asset is a productive resource (a major mining complex) with deep economic importance over centuries, not just a paper claim on a government that might default. ICOMOS emphasizes its enormous economic significance and long influence.  
2.There is evidence of institutional continuity across centuries (medieval documents → charter structure → modern corporate form → successor company history still tracked today).  
3.The ownership model was share-based early on, which is exactly what you want if the goal is “one investment that can survive” rather than a pile of valuables you’d have to conceal.  

Is “90%” provable? Not in a literal actuarial sense—history doesn’t give clean probabilities. But if your standard is “pick the option with the strongest real-world track record of surviving for ~700+ years,” this is about as close as you can get while staying within your rules.

What “spending $1000 (2026 USD)” means in practice

In 1300 you can’t hand someone modern dollars, so the practical equivalent is: you arrive with ~$1000 worth of widely recognized value (e.g., precious metal by weight), then convert that into the local transaction form to purchase a fractional mine share / share-right within the bergslag system.

The investment is the legally recognized share of a productive enterprise—not a hidden hoard.

items.title:
Claude’s answer:

## The Best Investment: A Contribution to an Islamic Waqf Endowment

**My recommen...
items.content:
Claude’s answer:

## The Best Investment: A Contribution to an Islamic Waqf Endowment

**My recommendation: Contribute $1,000 (2026 USD equivalent) to an established Islamic waqf endowment, specifically to a major educational or charitable institution like Al-Azhar in Cairo or the University of al-Qarawiyyin in Fez.**

-----

### Converting $1,000 (2026 USD) to 1300 Currency

A laborer earned £2 a year in 1300, which means  40 shillings, or 480 pence a year – or 2 pence a day. Using historical purchasing power comparisons and the fact that Crown revenues (at peace) were £30,000 circa 1300, and Barons earned £200-500+ per year , your $1,000 would translate to approximately **10-16 shillings** (120-192 silver pennies) in 1300.

This could buy you:

- A cottage (1 bay, 2 storeys) for £2 in early 14th century  - so you’d have roughly 25-40% of a small cottage
- Rent for a cottage at 5s/year  - about 2-3 years of cottage rent
- Several sheep or livestock

-----

### Why Islamic Waqf Beats All Other Options

**1. Legal Protection Unmatched in History**

A waqf is an inalienable charitable endowment under Islamic law. It typically involves donating a building, plot of land or other assets for Muslim religious or charitable purposes with no intention of reclaiming the assets. 

Critically, the inviolability of the waqf arrangement has traditionally provided security for the assets, which cannot be sold to pay a debt, be confiscated by a government that subscribes to Islamic law, or be used beyond their designated purpose. 

**2. Proven 700+ Year Survival Record**

Under the Mamluks, Al-Azhar gained influence and rose in prestige. The Mamluks established salaries for instructors and stipends for the students and gave the institution an endowment. A college was built for the institution in 1340, outside of the mosque. 

This is precisely the era you’d be investing in - and Al-Azhar still operates today as one of the world’s most prestigious Islamic institutions, having survived the Mongol invasions, Crusades, Ottoman conquest, Napoleonic invasion, British colonialism, and modern revolutions.

**3. Multiple Waqf Institutions from the 1300s Still Function**

The Al-Nuri Hospital, which operated for some 700 years, was the same hospital where Al-Mansur Qalawun was treated and inspired to establish his own hospital in Cairo.  The Bimaristan al-Nuri was founded in 1156 CE and operated continuously for centuries.

The Al-Mansuri Hospital was substantial, both in size and endowments. This hospital had the capability of holding 8000 beds and was funded off of annual endowments totaling one million dirhams… The Al-Mansuri Hospital remained operational through the 15th century CE and still stands in Cairo today, though it is now known as “Mustashfa Qalawun.” 

-----

### Why Other Options Fail the 90% Survival Test

**Land in Europe:**

- English land faced confiscation during the Wars of the Roses, Reformation, Civil War, and Enclosure Acts
- The Statutes of Mortmain of 1279 and 1290 were designed to prevent land from falling into the “dead hand” of the church, and thus depriving the Crown of future revenue. 

**Religious foundations in Christian Europe:**

- Massive destruction during the Reformation (1530s) - Henry VIII dissolved thousands of monasteries, almshouses, and charitable foundations

**Early bonds/financial instruments:**

- The lives of perpetual loans typically were “cut short by imprudent financing, government recall, or the misfortunes of wars and revolutions.” 
- The oldest bond that is still paying interest is one issued in 1624  - over 300 years after your target date, and even these are exceptionally rare survivors

-----

items.title: @0xDevShah I was just in Dubai and Abu Dhabi, and on the freeway, there are only luxury living signs...
items.content:
@0xDevShah I was just in Dubai and Abu Dhabi, and on the freeway, there are only luxury living signs and advertisements. This is a stark contrast to San Francisco, where you only see AI signs and advertisements.

The message is clear: if you have money, good living is happening down in Abu Dhabi. They even have a huge school and a massive data center dedicated specifically to AI. Perhaps the wealthy will get the message and decide to move to Abu Dhabi to set up shop there.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Compares advertising in Dubai/Abu Dhabi (luxury living) vs San Francisco (AI) and highlights Abu Dhabi's AI school and data center as potential draw for wealthy tech investors
items.reasoning: Highest engagement Scoble post in batch. First-hand geopolitical observations about Middle East AI investment. Notes infrastructure build-out.

items.title: @rywalker @rmcentush The problem with your statement is that there are always advantages to centrali...
items.content:
@rywalker @rmcentush The problem with your statement is that there are always advantages to centralization. Nerds like to hang out with other nerds; I hear this over and over again as the reason they don't leave the San Francisco Bay Area. They want to have smart neighbors who work in tech because it makes things more interesting at parties and cafes. If you come here, you'll see this firsthand. The serendipity of this area is unparalleled in the world, and that is why we love living here.

But look at Y Combinator:
1. It is a factory of startups—a centralized factory.
2. It only does well when everyone is together and can pitch 3,000 investors at the end of the class.

That is the whole point of Y Combinator and the startup ecosystem that now exists in San Francisco. Y Combinator has been copied by quite a few other rich people who have their own little "startup residencies," as they call them.

If those people leave, the whole thing leaves. While there is no reason Y Combinator specifically needs to be in San Francisco, it does need to be centralized in a city. Whoever ends up with Y Combinator is going to see a startup ecosystem start to grow around them. But of course, as pointed out elsewhere, you can't get everybody to move—and so we're just being squeezed, and we don't like it.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Detailed defense of tech centralization benefits, arguing Y Combinator's model requires physical proximity and that SF's serendipity is irreplaceable for startup ecosystems
items.reasoning: Thoughtful analysis of startup ecosystem dynamics and why centralization matters. Tangentially related to AI through startup ecosystem discussion but substantive argument.

That changes who gets to build.

items.title:
The real breakthrough is not speed.

It’s collapse of complexity.

Traditionally, building an app me...
items.content:
The real breakthrough is not speed.

It’s collapse of complexity.

Traditionally, building an app means coordinating:

→ frontend
→ backend
→ database
→ hosting
→ security
→ deployment

With AI agents, that entire stack becomes a single prompt.

That is a fundamental shift in how products get created.

items.title: @M_Zot_ike @pickle It looks awesome, but here's the rub: hardware is very hard to do at scale. It's ...
items.content:
@M_Zot_ike @pickle It looks awesome, but here's the rub: hardware is very hard to do at scale. It's difficult to get to that level because factories want to see a certain number of orders, and you must have both those orders and the money in hand to make them. It's a rough one.

Furthermore, once Apple is on the market, they are going to have Formula One level dominance. I’m going to lose a lot of sales just to that. There is so much stuff coming from the big companies that I just don't see how this competes long-term—but I'm willing to be shocked. 😔

The question is: do they last 18 months on my face?

I can't see how, which is the real problem for them as a company.

Having xAI be able to provide the brains for the following makes a lot of sense:
1. Neuralink
2. Tesla Robotaxi
3. Tesla Optimus
4. All the other things he's going to do

That makes a lot of sense. In that world, you almost want it to be a separate company so that it's clean and everyone can make deals with the separate entity without messing with their culture. That'll help optimize the whole network.

Those who understand this simple trick leverage it and become successful CEOs, politicians, popular artists, and other public figures whose success is based almost exclusively on lying.
